subject: Re: [junit] Proposed parameterized test syntax for JUnit 4
msgSnippet: ... I use a different rule, which gives quite different results. ;-) James Take care. ... [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
messageBody:
On 13/10/05, J. B. Rainsberger <jbrains@...> wrote:
>
> Eugene Kuleshov wrote:
> > J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> >
> > >> For instance, if you look at typical facade pattern, it is quite
> > >>often that it would change different parts of the internal state but
> > >>we still need to test it as a single entity. I am pretty sure that
> > >>facade is not only case for this.
> > >
> > > I have to admit that I can't make the connection between this
> paragraph
> > > and the subject of this thread.
> >
> > Let me give an example. Imagine you have a statefull facade under
> > test with has 5 methods: first one take no params, second - one param,
> > third - two params, etc.
> >
> > Should we follow your rules and break this facade into 5 classes?
> > Should we then write separate unit test class for each of those new
> classes?
>
> I still don't see the connection yet, so let me ask a question: do these
> 5 methods (among other things) initialize the same set of fields in the
> stateful bean? or completely different fields?
>
> If the answer is "the same set of fields", then I'd keep them on the
> same stateful bean class. This is the same as having 5 test cases that
> use the same fixture objects.
>
> If the answer is "completely different fields", then I absolutely would
> put them on separate stateful bean classes. I would think that was
> obvious. This is the same as having 5 test cases that use completely
> different fixture objects (and want them to be fields--that part is
> important).
>
> > The way I see it: there should be single test class with several
> > parameterized test cases (so several parm generators) and test case
> > would test a single test. In order to keep such construction compact you
> > can move most of the code into the declarative test definition, like how
> > input should look like and what to assert on the output, then test code
> > itself could just iterate trough the rules for each given test case
> > (before and then after test). Unfortunately this leads to soft-typed
> > dynamic bindings and evaluation and as a result practically usable only
> > in completely generated tests.
>
> That surprises me, since I have been using this technique successfully
> for five years with completely hand-written tests. I must be missing
> something you're trying to tell me.
>
> It seems like you really want a single test case per production code
> class. I have never wanted that, and I doubt I'll be able to convince
> you about why that's a bad idea. I suppose you benefit from it in a way
> that I don't. I doubt arguing over it will get us anywhere, so I'm
> offering you a draw on that topic.
>
> > > My point is pretty straightforward: we have these refactoring rules we
> > > often follow and we usually say that we should refactor tests like we
> > > refactor production code, so why wouldn't we apply these refactoring
> > > rules to tests?
> >
> > I don't quite agree with this. Tests should be simple enough to
> > require no refactorings at all. Applying OOP patters to the tests may
> > lead to fragile test code that will require too much maintenance,
> > especially if code under test is being structurally changed.
>
> This is /very/ interesting.
>
> "Applying OOP patterns to test may lead to fragile test code that will
> require too much maintenance."
>
> Shouldn't we then conclude that
>
> "Applying OOP patterns to any system may lead to fragile code that will
> require too much maintenance"?
>
> Are you saying that refactoring makes systems more fragile?
>
> (After all, please remember that test code is still just code.)
>
> > >> > Why wouldn't we follow those rules with JUnit test case classes?
> The
> > >> > first rule extracts common setup code into setUp() and fixture
> > objects.
> > >> > The second splits test case classes that have multiple fixtures
> into
> > >> > separate test case classes. This leads to test case classes
> organized
> > >> > around fixtures.
> > >> >
> > >> > As for one test case per model class, that's a natural place to
> start,
> > >> > because it's simple, but once that test case class becomes complex,
> > >> > refactor as usual.
> > >>
> > >> That usually would lead to confusion and will require special tools
> > >>to track down all the test cases for given class.
> > >
> > > I have /never/, /ever/ wanted to track down all the tests for a given
> > > class. I /have/ wanted to track down all the tests for a given
> /method/,
> > > which is dirt simple in any decent IDE. (In Eclipse, I hit
> Ctrl+Shift+G.)
> >
> > Can you then run ALL tests you found in a search view?
>
> Yes. I run all the tests, which includes all the tests I found in that
> search view. I run all the tests all the time.
>
> > Can these results guarantee that changed method under test didn't
> > affected other methods and you don't have to run all tests for them too?
>
> I suppose not, because I don't care about that: I run all the tests
> anyway.
>
> Let me ask you: how does keeping one test case class per production cod
> class "guarantee that changed method under test didn't affect other
> methods without running all the tests for them too"? How do you know the
> system-wide impact of a change without running all the tests for the
> entire system? (I don't think the way we organize tests helps us at all
> here.)
>
> > > You /believe/ this? or it's your experience? In my /experience/ it
> just
> > > isn't that much of an issue.
> >
> > It could be not an issue for unit testing of the isolated classes,
> > but it is quite different if those classes have more or less complex
> > dependencies (e.g. those that may be injected by IoC container in real
> > app, but mocked or stubbed in a test time). That perhaps problem with
> > the toolset because such testing usually introduces lot of dynamic
> > dependencies only resolved or even generated in the runtime.
>
> I notice you didn't answer my question, even though you wrote this
> directly underneath my question. :) I used to have a lot of very
> passionate opinions until I started following a simple rule: Don't claim
> X is better than Y until you've done both for a while and can measure
> the difference.


I use a different rule, which gives quite different results. ;-)

James

Take care.
